etymologies: Middle English (as a verb): perhaps from Low German rubben, of unknown ultimate origin. The noun dates from the late 16th century

definitions: move one's hand or a cloth repeatedly back and forth on the surface of (something) with firm pressure

examples.text: she rubbed her arm, where she had a large bruise
he rubbed at the dirt on his jeans

shortDefinitions: move one's hand or cloth repeatedly to and fro on surface of something with firm pressure

definitions: move (one's hand, a cloth, or another object) back and forth over a surface

examples.text: he rubbed a finger around the rim of his mug

shortDefinitions: move over surface in such way

definitions: (with reference to two things) to move or cause to move to and fro against each other with a certain amount of pressure and friction

examples.text: many insects make noises by rubbing parts of their bodies together
the ice breaks into small floes that rub against each other

shortDefinitions: to move or cause to move to and fro against each other with certain amount of pressure and friction

definitions: (of shoes or other hard items in contact with the skin) cause pain through friction

examples.text: badly fitting shoes can rub painfully

shortDefinitions: (of shoes or other hard items in contact with skin) cause pain through friction

definitions: make dry, clean, or smooth with pressure from a hand, cloth, or other object

examples.text: she found a towel and began rubbing her hair
she rubbed herself as dry as possible

shortDefinitions: make dry, clean, or smooth with pressure from object

definitions: spread (ointment, polish, or a substance of similar consistency) over a surface with repeated movements of one's hand or a cloth

examples.text: she took out her sunblock and rubbed some on her nose

shortDefinitions: spread over surface with repeated movements of one's hand or cloth

definitions: work an ingredient into (a mixture) by breaking and blending it with firm movements of one's fingers

examples.text: sift the flour into a bowl and rub in the fat

shortDefinitions: work ingredient into mixture by breaking and blending it with firm movements of one's fingers

definitions: reproduce the design of (a gravestone, memorial tablet, etc.) by laying paper on it and rubbing the paper with charcoal, colored chalk, etc.
shortDefinitions: reproduce design of (gravestone, memorial tablet, etc.) by laying paper on it and rubbing paper with charcoal

definitions: (of a bowl in lawn bowling) be slowed or diverted by the unevenness of the ground.
shortDefinitions: (of bowl) be slowed or diverted by unevenness of ground

phrases.text: not have two — to rub together

examples.text: she pulled out a towel and gave her head a quick rub

definitions: an ointment designed to be rubbed on the skin to ease pain
shortDefinitions: ointment designed to be rubbed on skin to ease pain

definitions: a mixture of spices and other seasonings that is applied to the surface of meat or fish before cooking

examples.text: he will be using coffee in a rub for a rack of lamb

shortDefinitions: mixture of seasonings applied to meat before cooking

definitions: a difficulty, especially one of central importance in a situation

examples.text: that was the rub—she had not cared enough

shortDefinitions: central problem or difficulty in situation

definitions: (in lawn bowling) an uneven patch of ground that impedes or diverts a bowl.
shortDefinitions: uneven patch of ground impeding or diverting bowl

phrases.text: not have two — to rub together
